de.bright_side.filesystemfacade.encryptedfs

Class EncryptedFS

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.bright_side.filesystemfacade.encryptedfs.EncryptedFS
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    FSFSystem

    public class EncryptedFS
extends Object
implements FSFSystem
    A file system which resides inside a sub-directory within another file system such as NativeFS ("normal" file system on the disk), DataBaseFS, on a data base, MemoryFS in Memory only (e.g. for unit tests), etc. All files and filenames are encrypted by a password. The used encryption module is BEAM (Basic Encryption Algorithm Module). The level of security is that regular users cannot read the data while hackers or government agencies are likely to be able to decrypt the data. Sample usage: FSFSystem fs = EncryptedFS(new NativeFS(), "This-is-the-password!", "/home/me/encrypted_dir"); fs.createByPath("/myFile.txt").writeString("My secret text"); String readText = fs.createByPath("/myFile.txt").readString();
    Author:
    Philip Heyse

      • EncryptedFS

        public EncryptedFS(FSFSystem innerFS,
                   String password,
                   String basePath)
            throws Exception
        Parameters:
        innerFS - inner file system on which the encrypted file system is based
        password - password that is used to encrypt and decrypt the data
        basePath - the path where the encrypted dir is located, e.g. "C:\\data\\myEncryptedDir"
        Throws:
        Exception - on general error

      • getInnerFS

        public FSFSystem getInnerFS()

      • toExistingInnerFileIfPossibleByParentAndName

        protected FSFFile toExistingInnerFileIfPossibleByParentAndName(FSFFile innerParentFile,
                                                               String plainFilename,
                                                               Long plainDataLength)
        for each plain file name there are multiple encrypted file names. This is because the encryption is done block-wise and if a block isn't full (which is usually the case for the last block) the remaining bytes are filled with random data. Hence each time an encrypted file name is generated, it is different (unless the length matches exactly 1 block).
        Parameters:
        plainDataLength: - null if unknown (e.g. because createByPath was called an no length was provided)
        innerParentFile - the inner parent file
        plainFilename - the filename in a not encrypted form
        plainDataLength - the length of the data if it wasn't encrypted
        Returns:
        the existing inner file if found

      • toExistingInnerFileIfPossible

        protected FSFFile toExistingInnerFileIfPossible(FSFFile innerFile)
        for each plain file name there are multiple encrypted file names. This is because the encryption is done block-wise and if a block isn't full (which is usually the case for the last block) the remaining bytes are filled with random data. Hence each time an encrypted file name is generated, it is different (unless the length matches exactly 1 block).
        Parameters:
        innerFile - the current inner file
        Returns:
        the new inner file

      • renameAccordingToLength

        protected void renameAccordingToLength(EncryptedFile file,
                                       long appendedLength,
                                       long writtenBytes)
                                throws IOException
        The file size is stored in the filename so that it can be returned without any processing logic. However the filename needs to be adjusted whenever the length of the file changes. This method performs that operation.
        Parameters:
        file - the file object which should be renamed
        appendedLength - if appended, the length before the appending. Otherwise 0
        writtenBytes - number of written bytes
        Throws:
        IOException - on general errors
